awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Development of an artificial iIntelligence (AI)-based, internet of things (IoT)-enabled system for structural health monitoring
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is the low-cost assessment of the health of structures or buildings.  Often property-owners and infrastructure managers do not have a true and fair view of the actual state of their building assets. Building health is assessed from infrequent inspections or monitoring that is often uneconomical for smaller structures. This project seeks to develop a technology that is able to discern structural anomalies to facilitate risk assessment and proper management. This technology seeks to  disrupt the growing market of structural health monitoring, providing an affordable solution for the assessment of the current state of buildings and structures with benefit to cost ratios over 10, installation costs ranging between $10 to $1,000 per control point and Software as a Service (SaaS) costs ranging between $10 and $500 per month. Once on the market, the technology may help to avoid dramatic human, environmental, and economic losses caused by damaged or collapsed buildings and structures.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project seeks to develop a proof of concept solution featuring Internet of Things (IoT) sensors and Artificial Intelligence (AI) to provide insights into the conditions of buildings remotely and automatically by analyzing natural structural vibrations. The solution targets structureal assets that currently are rarely assessed but entail risk of failure. The technology takes advantages of the fact that each structure has its own natural vibration signature, which depends on its design and materials, purpose, and environment. Hidden signals of anomalies, which can be associated with degradation, flaws, or failures, can be found encoded within this vibration signature. This novel technology uses AI to provide insight into these signals and translate them into valuable information about the health of structures. The project seeks to validate the degree to which anomalous data clusters obtained from buildings or structures can be associated with damage or defects and may help to establish the precision and accuracy in anomaly detection. The project comprises the monitoring of real buildings or structures and the manufacturing of the necessary IoT devices, the structural analyses through numerical modelling, laboratory experiments with physical models, and the use of AI to control hazard risk.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The principal technical objectives are to achieve better than human performance in the identification of anomalies, faults, or risk of failure, whilst dramatically reducing costs of monitoring for small to medium sized structures, of moderate to high complexity for example rail or road bridges using the concept of natural vibration monitoring. An Artificial Intelligence (AI) model is used to distinguish anomalies from a range of timeseries data obtained from an analogue to a structural component, modelled and experimentally verified at the Massachusetts at Lowell, Laboratory of Structural Dynamics and Acoustic Systems Laboratory. High accuracy was noted in a series of blind testing regime, well in excess of the range of expected human error.

Experimentally, a comparison was made between classically derived quantitative expectations of the deformation and/or vibration of a metal cantilever, excited by an external energy source (shaker), and Finite Element Analysis (FEA), as well as with a novel structural analysis device that uses a structures? natural vibrations. A Stainless-Steel cantilever beam was used to simulate a major structural component of a bridge or building, etc. External vibrational energy was the provided to the system and the FEA modelling was used to provide a complete understanding of the modes of vibration of the system, together with insight on the ideal locations of the various sensors in the network. These included accelerometers, strain gauges and novel, low-cost vibration sensors. Unlike many other studies, four different sensor types were used for data acquisition. Thus, specialized mode shapes were derived for the sensor network and was used to determine optimal locations.


Last Modified: 09/14/2023
Modified by: Graham Sutherland

Images (1 of )
  • The beam was designed and the 1st 9 natural frequencies were within the range of interest. An accurate Finite Element Modelling (FEM) created with equivalent boundary conditions matching expected frequencies and mode shapes as predicted by FEM. The proprietary code �ANSYS� was used to derive FEM.
    Graham Sutherland
    Copyrighted
    Graham Sutherland
    Figure 1. The base model test setup and detailed sensor locations on beam
  • Frequency sweep tests were first performed to experimentally assess the natural frequency response of the beam, and enable comparison with the outcomes from the FEM. These are shown below. Vertical lines corresponding to the natural frequencies obtained from FEM are also shown.
    Graham Sutherland
    Copyrighted
    Graham Sutherland
    Figure 2. Time traces for the frequency sweep-up experiment
  • A total of 33 main tests, including 3 blind tests, were completed. Dots on �Anomaly� column indicate the test complexity level. The 1st blind test�s anomaly data is found in Table 2. Presence of an anomaly is 1 dot and a double dot denotes increased complexity in the input energy.
    Graham Sutherland
    Copyrighted
    Graham Sutherland
    Signals from selected sensors in frequency domain
  • Neural Network architectures that obviated dataset labeling were examined using blind test methods to confirm accuracy and Gaussian noise and altered system boundary conditions to simulate real-world conditions. The anomaly detection system was finalized with thresholds according to a defined metric
    Graham Sutrherland
    Copyrighted
    Graham Sutherland
    Figure 4 ML Test Results
  • The experiment�s final stage assessed the individual performance of the 3 models with blind data. The last had multiple signals and white Gaussian noise beam excitation. 75 test sets created 300 tests as each had 4 unique sweep tests. Anomaly data was easily detected and model accuracy was 95%.
    Graham Sutherland
    Copyrighted
    Graham Sutherland
    Figure 5 - Confusion Matrix
  • It can be observed that provided blind data included a high number of normal data. Overall, model is highly successful in distinguishing between normal and anomaly data. For the blind test, 300 tests were provided and only 2 inaccurate predictions were done, so achieving 99% accuracy on this model.
    Graham Sutherland
    Copyrighted
    Graham Sutherland
    Figure 6. Test Results
